Buffon, A. Choplin, M. Leconte, J: M. Basset** Institut de Recherches sur la Catalyse, conventionne d l'Universite ci. Bernara, Lyon-1, 2 av. A. Einstein, 69 626 Yrlleurbanne Cedex (France) R. Touroude Laboratoire de Catalyse et Chimie de Surface, Universite L. Pasteur, 4 rue Blaise Pasca4 67 070 Strasbourg (France) and W. A. Herrmann Anorganisch-chemisches Institut der Technischen Universitat Munchen, Lichtenbergstrasse 4, D-8046 Garching (Germany) (Received October 7, 1991; accepted November 25, 1991) Re207 supported on alumina is one of the most active catalysts of practical use for the metathesis of olefins [2]. However, the exact coordination sphere of rhenium in the active species is as yet uncertain. This system becomes even more active, especially for the metathesis of functionalized olefins, when treated with tetraalkyltin complexes SnR4 (R = CH3, n-C4H9, etc . ...) [3]. Since Re207 is known to react with Sn(CH3)4 to form CH3Re03 (MTO) [4], it was suggested that the latter rhenium-alkyl complex could be an intermediate in the heterogeneous system. In solution, MTO is active for the metathesis of cyclic and acyclic olefins only in the presence of a Lewis acid and an alkylating agent. However, when supported on y-alumina and silica-alumina, it becomes an efficient metathesis catalyst, even for functionalized olefins [5]. More recently, a third very active system was found for acyclic olefins, namely MTO supported on niobium oxide [6]. In this last case, it was observed that the organic ligand of MTO remains on the surface: the question then arises as to whether this fragment is a methylene ligand or a methyl spectator ligand. *Communication 105 on 'Multiple Bonds between Main Group Elements and Transition Metals'. For the preceding communication, see [ 1 ]. **Author to whom correspondence should be addressed. 0304-5102/92/$5.00 0 1992 - Elsevier Sequoia. All rights reserved L8 To test this hypothesis, the catalyst MTO/Nb20b(300)* was exposed to the symmetrical olefin, traps-2,5-dimethyl-3-hexene. If a methylene species is present on the surface, the formation of only 3-methyl-l-butene should be observed, according to eqn. (1): [Re]~:= CHZ [Re] S [Re sJ (1) =/~ Formation of 3-methyl-l-butene (ca. 0.07 mol per mol grafted Re) is indeed observed. However, two C7 olefins, viz. 2,4-dimethyl-2-pentene (identified by GC-MS) and probably 5-methyl-2-hexene, and isobutene were also detected; these products cannot be accounted for by eqn. (1). Moreover, when the precursor complex MTO was labelled (99% enriched 13CH3Re03), GC-MS analysis revealed that 3-methyl-l-butene was not labelled**. The reaction in eqn. (2) thus did not occur on [Re15 MTO/Nb205: [Re]5 'aCH2 [Re]S (2) "C H It must therefore be concluded that the formation of the first metallacarbene, at least in the case of MTO/Nb206, does not arise from the methyl group but most likely from the olefin itself. Among all the mechanisms already proposed in the literature for the formation of a carbene surface species in the case of heterogeneous catalysts [8], only a 7r-allyl mechanism [9] would explain the formation of unlabelled. 3-methyl- I-butene (Scheme 1). According to this mechanism, after coordination of the olefin and formation of the 7rallyl intermediate, the resulting metallacyclobutane (1) should lead to the formation of isobutene and 3-methyl-l-butene. Isomerization can occur leading to the metallacyclobutane (2), which then leads to the formation of propene and 5-methyl-hexene. Under our reaction conditions, 3-methyl-l-butene was by far the major reaction product. This may mean that pathway (b) is largely '3CH3ReOg was synthesized as described in the literature [ 7]. Niobium oxide, Nth% - nH~O, obtained from C.B.M.M., was calcined at 450 C under a stream of OZ (1.2 L h'') overnight; after cooling to room temperature, it was contacted with water (22 torr) for ca. 3 h and then evacuated at 300 C overnight (10-' torr). A typical catalyst was prepared by in situ sublimation at room temperature (10-' torr). The olefin was then added and the products identified by GC-MS analysis. "The presence of only ca. 596 3-methyl-1 '3C-butene was detected, suggesting the occurrence of a very minor amount of surface [Re] ='3CHz (less than 0.3596 of the surface Re species). L9 IRe]s IRe1-H s [Re]' H + IRe]~ [Re]a Scheme 1. favored. Only traces of propene could be detected. Formation of small amounts of 2,5-dimethyl-2-pentene could result from the secondary reaction between the initially formed rhenium-isopropylidene complex and 2,5-dimethylhexene (eqn. (3)). IRe1$~ IRels--"~ (3) Based on this mechanism and on the amount of 3-methyl-l-butene formed, we can estimate that at least 7ss'o of the rhenium surface species are active sites. Upon formulating such a mechanism, one implicitly assumes that, at the surface of niobium oxide, some of the rhenium has reached a lower oxidation state, which must be equal or lower than +V in order to allow the formation of a metallacycle, which will bring the rhenium back to the oxidation state + VII. A preliminary analysis of MTO/NbZOb by ESCA indeed L10 reveals the presence of reduced rhenium on the surface, which could be either Re(V) or Re(M; the number of these reduced species decreases after reaction with an olefin.
